    Theming recipes

    Carson Sievert

    2020-01-24

    recipes.Rmd

    DISCLAIMER: This document demonstrates what’s possible today with bootstraplib theming and is still very much a work in progress. It should become more complete and keep improving in the coming months.

    The following sections contain some “recipes” for high-level theming shiny apps and rmarkdown documents via bootstraplib. For the sake of novelty and convenience, many of the examples here focus on theming shiny apps with Bootstrap 4 Sass, but many of the same ideas can translate to rmarkdown and Bootstrap 3 Sass as well (if you’d like to theme via Bootstrap 3 Sass, also consider using the fresh package). Since most of the examples are based on shiny, you’ll see repeated use of bs_theme_new() to start a new theme; however in rmarkdown, you won’t need to start a new theme because it’s done for you via the rmarkdown::html_document arguments: bootstrap_version and theme.

    For those looking to learn more about the foundational bootstraplib and sass tools that make these recipes possible, see the foundations article.

    Main colors

    Bootstrap 4 has two variables for setting the body’s foreground ($body-color) and background color ($body-bg). These provide the highest level control over the majority colors.

    bs_theme_new()
bs_theme_add_variables(
  "body-bg" = "#6c757d",
  "body-color" = "white"
)
bs_theme_preview()

    You’ll notice that there are certain Bootstrap components, like navigation tabs, that don’t pick up on $body-color in the way you might expect. For example, $nav-tabs-link-active-color doesn’t inherit from $body-color, so if your application uses tabsetPanel(), you’d probably also want that variable to match $body-color (See here for more on theming navigation).

    The other main entrypoint to color styling are theme colors. Shiny’s buttons use the secondary theme color, but you can also add a class = "btn-primary" for it to use the primary color:

    bs_theme_add_variables(
  "nav-tabs-link-active-color" = "white",
  "primary" = "salmon",
  "secondary" = "lime"
)
bs_theme_preview()

    Fonts

    In Bootstrap 4, there are two main Sass variables for controling font families: $font-family-base and $font-family-monospace, and one for controling the base size: $font-size-base. There are a handful of other variables for controling things like font weight and header styling, but these are the quickest and easiest entrypoints:

    bs_theme_add_variables(
  "font-family-base" = "Roboto Slab",
  "font-family-monospace" = "Monaco",
  "font-size-base" = "0.9rem"
)
bs_theme_preview()

    For non-standard fonts that may not exist on the system, you may want to consider downloading the relevant font files and serving those font files with your application. The gfonts package offers a nice way to download fonts from Google Fonts and generating the styling rules necessary to import the font files, which we can incorporate as part of the current theme:

    library(gfonts)
# download_font("montserrat", output_dir = "www/fonts")
bs_theme_new()
bs_theme_add(
  defaults = list("font-family-base" = "Montserrat"),
  rules = generate_css("montserrat", font_dir = "www/fonts")
)
# This code is assuming we have an app in the current directory
shiny::runApp()

    Buttons

    Core shiny UI functions like downloadButton() and actionButton() emit HTML markup with the BS3 btn-default class, which was dropped in BS4. When version = "4-3", this class extends the BS4 btn-secondary class, which is why, given our theme has $secondary: lime, the actionButton() appears lime (by default). However, you can easily change the background color to any theme color with the btn-* class modifiers. The text color will try and automatically contrast (i.e., flip between white and black) based on the background color, but if you want more control over the text color, use the text utility classes.

    fluidPage(
  bootstrap(),
  actionButton("action", "Search", class = "text-primary"),
  actionButton("id", "Action", class = "btn-primary text-secondary m-1")
)

    It’s worth noting that not every shiny UI function will allow you to add classes this easily, but in those cases, you can use the shiny::tagAppendAttributes() function to add class attributes to the tag.

    Wells

    Core shiny UI functions like wellPanel() and sidebarPanel() are based on the BS3 well class. When version = "4-3", this class extends the BS4 card class, making it feasible to style wells using some of the card theming variables, like the border and spacing variables. We also use our own $well-bg variable to set the background color to get the right default styling:

    bs_theme_add_variables(
  "well-bg" = "#343a40",
  "card-border-color" = "darken($well-bg, 3%)",
  "card-border-radius" = 0,
  "card-border-width" = "0.5rem"
)
bs_theme_preview()

    Plots

    A future version of shiny, renderPlot() will be able to use it’s foreground/background color to automatically apply an intelligent default theme to ggplot2, lattice, and base graphics. That means, even if you’ve only changed $body-bg and $body-color, your plots should inherit them and look consistent with the rest of your app’s styling.

    # remotes::install_github("rstudio/shiny#2740")
shiny::runGitHub("shiny-examples", "rstudio", "autoColors", "181-autocolors")

    Tables

    DT

    A future version of DT will gain the ability to automatically theme itself based on currently set bootstraplib theme, which works with DT::dataTableOutput() inside shiny and DT::datatable() in rmarkdown.

    bs_theme_new(bootswatch = "solar")
fluidPage(bootstrap(), DT::datatable(mtcars))

    For more granular control, you can set the relevant Bootstrap Sass variables, like $table-color and $table-bg. The upside of doing this is that you can theme both DT::dataTableOutput() as well as the more basic shiny::dataTableOutput() all at once. Alternatively, you can also override dataTables Sass variable defaults using DT::datatableThemeVariables(). The upside of doing this is that you can theme DT outside of shiny and rmarkdown and without depending on Bootstrap.

    Basic

    Theming basic shiny::dataTableOutput() should “just work” in the sense of automatically inheriting from $body-color and $body-bg, but if you need to, you can also set $table-color, $table-bg, and handful of other variables.

    Navigation

    Both shiny and rmarkdown allow you create so called “tabset panels”, which are built on top of Bootstrap’s nav API. These tabsets come in two different flavors: tabs and pills. Below is a table showing how to create either flavor of navigation in both shiny and rmarkdown. We’ll walk through theming with tabs (i.e., tabsetPanel()) and pills (i.e., navlistPanel()) in shiny, but it’s worth noting that the same ideas apply to rmarkdown’s tabbed sections as well.

    shiny rmarkdown
    tabs tabsetPanel() {.tabset}
    pills navlistPanel() {.tabset .tabset-pills}

    Pills

    Let’s start with a basic navlistPanel(), which is based on Bootstrap nav pills:

    library(shiny)
library(bootstraplib)

ui_content <- navlistPanel(
  tabPanel("One", "One"),
  tabPanel("Two", icon = icon("download"), "Two"),
  navbarMenu("A submenu",
             tabPanel("Three", "Three"),
             "---",
             tabPanel("Four", "Four"),
             tabPanel("Five", "Five")
  )
)

# Clear the current theme
bs_theme_new()

# Resuable function to preview our theming changes
preview_pills <- function() {
  shinyApp(
    fluidPage(bootstrap(), ui_content), 
    function(input, output) {}
  )
}
preview_pills()

    Bootstrap 4 currently exposes 3 different Sass variables specifically for pill styling, including the foreground and background color of active pills:

    $nav-pills-link-active-color: $component-active-color !default;
$nav-pills-link-active-bg:    $component-active-bg !default;

    Importantly, these active colors default to variables that control the active color of all Bootstrap components, and by default, the primary theme color controls the active color:

    $component-active-color:      $white !default;
$component-active-bg:         theme-color("primary") !default;

    Therefore, we could just change the primary theme color to get a different active color scheme.

    bs_theme_new()
bs_theme_add_variables(
  "primary" = "orange",
  "nav-pills-border-radius" = 0,
)
preview_pills()

    If you wanted the bg color of the active pills directly, you could set $nav-pills-link-active-bg; but in that case, you should also set $dropdown-link-active-bg (which controls navbarMenu()’s active bg color) as well as $link-color (which controls the non-active pill text color).

    bs_theme_new()
bs_theme_add_variables(
  "nav-pills-link-active-bg" = "orange",
  "dropdown-link-active-bg" = "orange",
  "link-color" = "orange"
)

    Tabs

    Let’s start with a basic tabsetPanel(), which is based on Bootstrap nav pills:

    library(shiny)
library(bootstraplib)

ui_content <- tabsetPanel(
  tabPanel("One", "One"),
  tabPanel("Two", icon = icon("download"), "Two"),
  navbarMenu("A submenu",
             tabPanel("Three", "Three"),
             "---",
             tabPanel("Four", "Four"),
             tabPanel("Five", "Five")
  )
)

bs_theme_new()

# Resuable function to preview our theming changes
preview_tabs <- function() {
  shinyApp(
    fluidPage(bootstrap(), ui_content), 
    function(input, output) {}
  )
}
preview_tabs()

    For the most part the variable defaults for tabs work well with lighter themes, but for darker themes, you’ll likely want to set $nav-tabs-link-active-color to something similar to $body-color. Also, it’s not obvious from the variables file, but the non-active tab text color derives from $link-color, which defaults to $primary. So if you want to change the non-active tab color without changing $primary, set $link-color (and also $dropdown-link-active-bg) if your tabs have dropdowns.

    bs_theme_add_variables(
  "body-bg" = "#6c757d",
  "body-color" = "white",
  "nav-tabs-link-active-color" = "white",
  # Non-active tab/link styling
  "link-color" = "lime",
  # For dropdown
  "dropdown-link-active-bg" = "lime",
)
preview_tabs()
